cab.content: Printed for the Cabinet. March 1927.SECRET. Copy No. 01CP. 81 (27).CABINET.EQUAL FRANCHISE.Memorandum by the Home Secretary.AT my request the Registrar-General has prepared a Table showing in respect of each constituency in England and Wales the estimated effect of an extension of the franchise to women, at the ages of 21, 25, and 30 respectively, on the same terms in other respects as the present male franchise. The Table is of great interest and will, I think, be useful to my colleagues in the consideration of the question of the extension of the franchise. I therefore circulate it to them at once.It will be seen that, in addition to giving the actual estimated increase in each constituency7, the Table also gives two index figures showing the effect of extension from the point of view of redistribution and the effect from the point of view of the relative weight of the two sexes in the electorate.It must be remembered that the figures given are estimates only, made at some distance of time from the date of the last census; and that they are based upon the available statistics as to the sex and age composition of the population of the respective constituencies, and do not purport to take into account any special local characteristics which are not reflected or expressed in the statistical material. Estimates for sub-divisions of the country are, of course, bound to be somewhat more fallible than estimates based upon the same material for the country as a whole. The, Registrar-General nevertheless thinks it true to say that the figures give as complete and accurate estimates as the available material permits or as could be obtained from any other source.The Registrar-General has also analysed the Table from the point of view of (1) the sex proportions in the electorate on the alternative bases, and (2) the effect of the alternative bases upon the proportions of the electorates to the "quota" in each case. By7 " quota " is meant the result arrived at by dividing the total electorate as estimated on each alternative basis by7 the number of seats. The results are as follows : 1. Analysis of proportions of Women to Men Voters [England and Wales).Women per 100 men. Number of Constituencies. Existing Electorate. Number of Constituencies. Existing Electorate. New Electorate the franchise age for women being 21 25 30 50- 59 . . ...... 4 "2 3 3 60- 69...... 12 12 12 10 70-79 ........ 41 49 49 47 80-89 ........ 85 91 92 87 90-99 ........ 125 ' 124 119 125 100-109 :..... 101 101 103 106 110-119 ........ 75 60 61 61 120-129 ........ 30 31 31 31 130-139 ....... 15 13 13 13 140-149 ........ 12 20 20 21 150 and over 9 6 6 ' 5 As regards the sex proportions, it will be seen that the effect of any of the new proposals is to shift the proportions of women to men from the lower to the higher percentages. This was of course to be expected. The, second analysis is, however, very instructive and striking. It will be seen that the range of disproportion between the electorate in different constituencies and the quota is very wide, reaching from cases in which the electorate is only half the quota to cases in which it is more than one-and-a-half times the quota. But the interesting thing is that the new alternative bases hardly affect the position in this respect. Indeed, on the new bases the numbers of constituencies at either extreme are even reduced. There would appear, therefore, to be very good ground on these figures for taking the view that any case for redistribution arises solely out of the existing conditions, and will not be strengthened by either of the alternative new proposals.A similar Table has been prepared for Scotland by the Scottish Registrar-General, which is also appended. It gives the following results : I. Analysis of proportions of Women to Men Voters (Scotland).Women per 100 men. Number of Constituencies. Existing Electorate.
